intro.p: Back in the tutoring lab, you're helping a student {{stu}} with a homework exercise on polynomials. Yet again, {{pn}} didn't write down the steps {{pn}} used to arrive at the following two incorrect answers:
Help {{stu}} both to understand how a single error led to {{ppn}} incorrect answer in each case.

content.p: In part (a), first do the simplification correctly yourself, showing all your steps.
Then, looking at your correct work, identify one common algebra error that {{stu}} might have made that would have led to the incorrect answer {{wexpr}}.
Explain to {{stu}} how to avoid this error in the future.

outtro.p: The correct simplification for part (a) is {{ans1}}.
Probably {{stu}} arrived at the incorrect answer {{wexpr}} by {{reason1}}.

content.p: In part (b), first demonstrate for {{stu}} how to check {{ppn}} factoring work so {{pn}} can see why {{wexpr2}} is incorrect.
Then, knowing that (x - {{p}}) is one correct factor, determine a correct factorization for this polynomial, explaining your work.

outtro.p: Multiplying out {{stu}}'s answer to part (b) should arrive at {{wexpand}}, not {{expr2}}.
A correct factorization would be {{fans}}, found, e.g., by grouping the factor (x-{{p}}).
